# Task

Write a function `wrap_string`. It iterates over words and it will add a new line each time a maximum `text_width::Int=10` would be exceeded. Provide an example



# Special Instructions

None.

```julia
function wrap_string(words, text_width::Int = 10)
    lines = []
    current_line = ""
    
    for word in words
        if length(current_line) + length(word) <= text_width
            # Add the word to the current line
            current_line *= " $word"
        else
            # The current line is full, add it to lines
            push!(lines, current_line)
            
            # Start a new line with the current word
            current_line = "$word"
        end
    end
    
    # Add the last line to the output
    push!(lines, current_line)

    return join(lines, "\n")
end

# Example usage:
words = ["Here", "are", "some", "words"]
wrapped_text = wrap_string(words)
println(wrapped_text)
```

In this example, `wrap_string` takes a list of words and an optional `text_width` parameter. It breaks the words into lines that do not exceed the specified width.

The function returns a string with the wrapped text. In the example usage, we create an array of words, call `wrap_string`, and print the result.
